parts.text: What is a major chord?

A major chord is like a musical handshake - three notes that just belong together.
[MOMENT]
Let's start with just the foundation - [AUDIO:60:0.8:C root]
Now listen to what happens when we add the major third - [AUDIO:60,64:1.5:C with E]
Feel how that brightens things up?
[MOMENT]
And when we complete it with the fifth - [AUDIO:60,64,67:2.5:Full C Major]
That's the sound of home in music.
Show me the C major scale

The C major scale is music's alphabet - seven notes that define so much of what we hear.
[MOMENT]
Let's walk up each step:
[MIDI:60@0-0.5,62@0.6-0.5,64@1.2-0.5,65@1.8-0.5,67@2.4-0.5,69@3.0-0.5,71@3.6-0.5,72@4.2-0.5:C Major Scale Ascending]
[MOMENT]
Notice how some notes feel like they want to keep going? That tension and release is what makes melodies work.
What's a perfect fifth?

A perfect fifth is rock music's best friend - it's that powerful, hollow sound you hear in power chords.
[MOMENT]
Here's our C - [AUDIO:60:0.8:C]
And here's G, seven semitones up - [AUDIO:67:0.8:G]
Now together - [AUDIO:60,67:2.5:Perfect Fifth]
[MOMENT]
Hear that open, stable quality? It's so fundamental that medieval musicians called it 'perfect' - and we still do.
Play Bach Prelude in C
What makes a chord major vs minor?

One tiny change, massive emotional shift. It's all about that third note.
[MOMENT]
Here's C major - bright and open - [AUDIO:60,64,67:2.0:C Major]
Now drop the E to Eb for C minor - [AUDIO:60,63,67:2.0:C Minor]
[MOMENT]
Just one semitone down, but suddenly we've gone from sunshine to shadow. That's the power of the third.
Can you show me chord inversions?

Inversions are like looking at the same chord from different angles - same notes, new perspective.
[MOMENT]
Root position C major - solid and grounded - [AUDIO:60,64,67:2.0:Root Position]
First inversion - lighter, floating - [AUDIO:64,67,72:2.0:First Inversion]
Second inversion - unstable, wants to move - [AUDIO:67,72,76:2.0:Second Inversion]
[MOMENT]
Same three notes, but each arrangement tells a different story.
How do intervals work?

Intervals are the distance between notes - they're the building blocks of everything in music.
[MOMENT]
Let's start small - here's a minor second, just one semitone - [AUDIO:60,61:1.5:Minor 2nd - Tense]
Now a major third, four semitones - [AUDIO:60,64:1.5:Major 3rd - Bright]
And that perfect fifth we love - [AUDIO:60,67:2.0:Perfect 5th - Stable]
[MOMENT]
Each interval has its own personality - combine them and you get harmony.
What's a dominant seventh chord?

The dominant seventh is music's question mark - it creates tension that demands an answer.
[MOMENT]
Start with G major - [AUDIO:67,71,74:1.8:G Major]
Now add F to make G7 - [AUDIO:67,71,74,77:2.0:G7 - Tension]
[MOMENT]
Feel that pull? It wants to resolve to C - [AUDIO:60,64,67:2.5:C Major - Resolution]
That's the sound that drives the blues and makes jazz swing.
Show me a I-IV-V progression

The I-IV-V is rock and roll's DNA - three chords that built a thousand hits.
[MOMENT]
[MIDI:60@0-1.8,64@0-1.8,67@0-1.8,65@2.0-1.8,69@2.0-1.8,72@2.0-1.8,67@4.0-1.8,71@4.0-1.8,74@4.0-1.8,60@6.0-2.5,64@6.0-2.5,67@6.0-2.5:I-IV-V-I Progression]
C to F to G and back home - that's the journey that never gets old.
What's the difference between major and minor thirds?

One semitone changes everything - it's the difference between a smile and a frown in music.
[MOMENT]
Major third - four semitones, bright and confident - [AUDIO:60,64:2.0:Major Third]
Minor third - three semitones, darker and introspective - [AUDIO:60,63:2.0:Minor Third]
[MOMENT]
That single half-step is what separates happy birthday from a funeral dirge.
Explain suspended chords

Suspended chords create anticipation - they replace the third with something that wants to resolve.
[MOMENT]
Here's C major for reference - [AUDIO:60,64,67:1.8:C Major]
Now Csus4 - replacing E with F - [AUDIO:60,65,67:2.0:Csus4 - Suspended]
Hear how it wants to fall back? - [AUDIO:60,64,67:2.0:Resolved to C]
[MOMENT]
That suspension and release is musical gravity at work.
How do you build tension in music?

Tension in music is like stretching a rubber band - the further you go, the more it wants to snap back.
[MOMENT]
Start stable with C major - [AUDIO:60,64,67:1.5:Home]
Move to G7, adding that unstable seventh - [AUDIO:67,71,74,77:2.0:Building Tension]
Then release back home - [AUDIO:60,64,67:2.5:Sweet Resolution]
[MOMENT]
That cycle of tension and release is what makes music breathe.
What are chord extensions?

Extensions add color beyond the basic triad - like adding spices to a recipe.
[MOMENT]
Basic C major - [AUDIO:60,64,67:1.8:C Triad]
Add the major seventh for Cmaj7 - [AUDIO:60,64,67,71:2.0:Cmaj7 - Jazzy]
Add the ninth for Cmaj9 - [AUDIO:60,64,67,71,74:2.5:Cmaj9 - Lush]
[MOMENT]
Each extension adds sophistication, taking us from folk to jazz.
Show me parallel versus contrary motion

Motion between voices creates different textures - like dancers moving together or apart.
[MOMENT]
Parallel motion - both voices moving the same direction:
[MIDI:60@0-0.5,64@0-0.5,62@0.6-0.5,66@0.6-0.5,64@1.2-0.5,68@1.2-0.5:Parallel Motion]
[MOMENT]
Contrary motion - voices moving opposite directions:
[MIDI:60@0-0.5,67@0-0.5,62@0.6-0.5,65@0.6-0.5,64@1.2-0.5,63@1.2-0.5:Contrary Motion]
Feel how contrary motion creates more independence between the lines?
What's a plagal cadence?

The plagal cadence is the 'Amen' cadence - that warm, settling feeling at the end of hymns.
[MOMENT]
It goes from IV to I - here's F major - [AUDIO:65,69,72:2.0:F Major (IV)]
Resolving to C major - [AUDIO:60,64,67:2.5:C Major (I)]
[MOMENT]
Less dramatic than V-I, but with its own gentle finality - like a musical sigh of contentment.
Explain the circle of fifths

The circle of fifths is music's map - it shows how all keys relate through perfect fifth jumps.
[MOMENT]
Start at C - [AUDIO:60:0.8:C]
Up a fifth to G - [AUDIO:67:0.8:G]
Up another fifth to D - [AUDIO:74:0.8:D]
And so on - [MIDI:60@0-0.5,67@0.6-0.5,74@1.2-0.5,69@1.8-0.5,64@2.4-0.5:Fifth Jumps]
[MOMENT]
Keep going and you'll circle back to C - it's music's perfect loop.
What makes a chord diminished?

Diminished chords are music's anxiety - everything is compressed and unstable.
[MOMENT]
C major for reference - spread out and stable - [AUDIO:60,64,67:2.0:C Major]
Now C diminished - both thirds are minor - [AUDIO:60,63,66:2.0:C Diminished]
[MOMENT]
That squeezed, tense sound is perfect for transitions - it desperately wants to resolve somewhere, anywhere.
How do pedal tones work?

A pedal tone holds steady while harmony moves above it - like an anchor in shifting waters.
[MOMENT]
Listen to the low C holding while chords change above:
[MIDI:48@0-4.0,60@0-1.5,64@0-1.5,67@0-1.5,60@1.6-1.5,65@1.6-1.5,69@1.6-1.5,60@3.2-1.5,62@3.2-1.5,67@3.2-1.5:Pedal Tone Example]
[MOMENT]
That constant bass creates both stability and tension as the harmony travels over it.
What's voice leading?

Voice leading is how individual notes move between chords - smooth transitions versus jumpy ones.
[MOMENT]
Good voice leading - minimal movement:
[MIDI:60@0-1.5,64@0-1.5,67@0-1.5,60@1.6-1.5,65@1.6-1.5,69@1.6-1.5:Smooth Voice Leading]
[MOMENT]
Now with larger jumps - more dramatic:
[MIDI:60@0-1.5,64@0-1.5,67@0-1.5,53@1.6-1.5,69@1.6-1.5,72@1.6-1.5:Dramatic Jumps]
Smooth voice leading connects chords like silk, while jumps create emphasis.
Show me chromatic movement

Chromatic movement uses every semitone - it's music's way of sliding between notes.
[MOMENT]
Here's a chromatic line climbing from C:
[MIDI:60@0-0.3,61@0.4-0.3,62@0.8-0.3,63@1.2-0.3,64@1.6-0.3,65@2.0-0.3,66@2.4-0.3,67@2.8-0.3:Chromatic Ascent]
[MOMENT]
That sliding quality creates tension and momentum - like musical quicksand pulling you forward.
What's an augmented chord?

Augmented chords stretch the fifth upward - creating a mysterious, unsettled quality.
[MOMENT]
C major - normal and stable - [AUDIO:60,64,67:2.0:C Major]
C augmented - that raised fifth makes it float - [AUDIO:60,64,68:2.0:C Augmented]
[MOMENT]
It's neither major nor minor - just suspended in musical space, often used in film scores for that dreamlike effect.
How do modes work?

Modes are different flavors of scales - same notes, different starting points, totally different moods.
[MOMENT]
C major scale (Ionian mode) - [MIDI:60@0-0.4,62@0.5-0.4,64@1.0-0.4,65@1.5-0.4,67@2.0-0.4,69@2.5-0.4,71@3.0-0.4,72@3.5-0.4:C Ionian]
[MOMENT]
Now start from D (Dorian mode) - same notes, darker feel - [MIDI:62@0-0.4,64@0.5-0.4,65@1.0-0.4,67@1.5-0.4,69@2.0-0.4,71@2.5-0.4,72@3.0-0.4,74@3.5-0.4:D Dorian]
Each mode has its own character - from bright Lydian to dark Phrygian.
What's a tritone?

The tritone is music's devil - literally called 'diabolus in musica' in medieval times.
[MOMENT]
It's exactly half an octave - six semitones of pure tension:
[AUDIO:60,66:2.5:The Tritone - Maximum Tension]
[MOMENT]
That unstable interval wants desperately to resolve - either in to [AUDIO:59,67:1.5:Resolution In] or out to [AUDIO:60,67:1.5:Resolution Out]
It's what gives dominant sevenths their drive.
Explain quartal harmony

Quartal harmony stacks fourths instead of thirds - creating an open, modern sound.
[MOMENT]
Traditional thirds-based C major - [AUDIO:60,64,67:2.0:Tertian Harmony]
Now stacking fourths from C - [AUDIO:60,65,70:2.0:Quartal Harmony]
[MOMENT]
That wider spacing creates ambiguity - it's neither clearly major nor minor, which is why jazz and film composers love it.
What's the Neapolitan chord?

The Neapolitan is a major chord built on the lowered second degree - it adds drama before resolution.
[MOMENT]
In C, that's Db major - an unexpected visitor - [AUDIO:61,65,68:2.0:Neapolitan (Db major)]
It typically moves to the dominant G - [AUDIO:67,71,74:1.8:G Major]
Then home to C - [AUDIO:60,64,67:2.5:C Major]
[MOMENT]
That Db to G motion creates a powerful pull back to C - very dramatic and romantic.
How do you modulate between keys?

Modulation is like walking through a door from one room to another - you need a pivot chord that exists in both keys.
[MOMENT]
We're in C major - [AUDIO:60,64,67:1.5:C Major]
A minor works in both C and G major - [AUDIO:69,72,76:1.8:A Minor (pivot)]
Now we can move to G major - [AUDIO:67,71,74:2.0:G Major - New Key]
[MOMENT]
That shared chord is our bridge between worlds.
What's a deceptive cadence?

A deceptive cadence is music's plot twist - you expect to go home but end up somewhere else.
[MOMENT]
Set up with G7, creating expectation - [AUDIO:67,71,74,77:2.0:G7 - Expecting C]
But instead of C, we go to A minor - [AUDIO:69,72,76:2.5:A Minor - Surprise!]
[MOMENT]
That unexpected turn keeps the music going when you thought it would end - it's delightfully unsettling.
Show me compound intervals

Compound intervals span more than an octave - they're simple intervals stretched across space.
[MOMENT]
A major third within one octave - [AUDIO:60,64:1.5:Simple Major 3rd]
Now the same interval across octaves (major 10th) - [AUDIO:60,76:2.0:Compound Major 10th]
[MOMENT]
Same harmonic relationship, but that extra space creates openness - it's why pianists love to spread their voicings.
What's a passing tone?

Passing tones are the notes between the notes - they connect chord tones smoothly.
[MOMENT]
Here's C to E directly - [AUDIO:60,64:1.5:Direct Jump]
Now with D as a passing tone between them:
[MIDI:60@0-0.5,62@0.6-0.3,64@1.0-0.5:With Passing Tone]
[MOMENT]
That D isn't part of the C major chord, but it makes the melody flow like water instead of jumping.
Explain borrowed chords

Borrowed chords steal from the parallel minor or major - adding unexpected colors to your key.
[MOMENT]
We're in C major, but let's borrow F minor from C minor - [AUDIO:65,68,72:2.0:F Minor (borrowed)]
It adds sudden darkness before returning to G - [AUDIO:67,71,74:1.8:G Major]
And home to C - [AUDIO:60,64,67:2.0:C Major]
[MOMENT]
That borrowed chord is like a shadow passing through sunlight.
